Clever characters can buy twenty steel mirrors (5 gp each) and arrange them in places (and at the proper angles) so that sunlight from outside can be reflected underground and shone upon the vault entrance. Setting up these mirrors and getting their alignment just right takes {@dice 2d4 + 2} hours regardless of the number of characters involved.

entries.name: Unicorn
entries: Although conjuring up a real unicorn is likely beyond the abilities of the characters, they could ask {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH} or {@creature Vajra Safahr|WDH} to cast the {@spell conjure celestial} spell. The characters can gain an audience with Laeral or Vajra through {@creature Renaer Neverember|wdh} or another well-connected NPC. If the characters tell Laeral or Vajra the truth about the Vault of Dragons and promise to turn the gold over to the authorities, either one agrees to accompany the characters to the vault and cast the spell. The unicorn need not be a real unicorn to serve as this key. The Sea Maidens Faire (see chapter 7) uses a unicorn float in its parades, and a stuffed unicorn can be found in Cassalanter Villa (see chapter 6, {@area C18|317}).

entries.title: A gold dragon guards a pile of golden dragons

entries.name: Vault of Dragons
entries: Once the characters have the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, they can use it to determine the location of the Vault of Dragons and the keys needed to enter it.

entries.name: Vault Features
entries: All areas of the vault have the following features:

items: Any spell that tries to contact a creature in the vault fails, as does any spell that attempts to scry on the vault interior or any creatures within. Teleporting into the vault from outside is impossible.
Walls are made of mortared stone. Doors are solid stone slabs with stone handles and hinges.
Except in {@area V9|24b}, there are no light sources.

entries.name: Areas of the Vault
entries: The following locations are keyed to map 4.9.

entries.name: V1. Vault Door
entries: A 20-foot-high, 20-foot-wide stone corridor ends before an adamantine double door bearing Dwarvish runes. The doors have neither handles nor hinges. The writing on them reads, "THE THREE KEYS. BRING THEM FORTH."

The doors part, sliding back into the walls, when the three correct keys are brought within 5 feet of them. They remain open until {@creature Aurinax|WDH} or someone else speaks the command word to close them ("Azaam"). The keys can open the doors from either side. The doors can't be forced open or damaged in any way, and attempts to circumvent them with magic fail automatically.

items: Three age-worn columns support crumbling stone bridges 60 feet overhead, with the ceiling rising another 20 feet beyond that.
Set into alcoves are twelve sets of double doors made of iron. Each door is 10 feet wide, 10 feet high, and embossed with images of dwarf warriors in plate armor.

entries.name: Crumbling Bridges
entries: The bridges connect {@area V4|23f} to adamantine doors that seal off areas V6, V7, and V8. The eastern half of the northern bridge and the western half of the southern bridge are unstable. Either bridge collapses if more than 150 pounds of weight is applied to it. A creature standing on a section of bridge when it collapses must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or fall 60 feet to the floor below.

The middle bridge has a 15-foot-wide gap in it. A character can clear this gap with a running jump-but part of the bridge breaks away under the character's feet on landing, forcing the character to succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or fall to the floor below.

entries.name: Iron Doors
entries: Ten of the double doors are false and refuse to budge. The two sets of doors at the northern end of the west wall push open to reveal {@area V3|23d} beyond.

entries.name: V3. Stairs and Fresco
entries: This hall has the following features:

items: At the south end of this chamber, expertly carved stairs climb 70 feet to {@area V4|23f}.
The north wall bears a 20-foot-square fresco that depicts dwarves battling goblins.

entries.name: Enthralling Fresco
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of enchantment magic on the fresco. Any creature within 30 feet of the fresco that can see it must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by it for 24 hours. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the creature can't willingly move out of sight of the fresco and defends it to the death. If forcibly moved away from the fresco, the creature tries to find its way back. The creature can't rest while under this effect. After 24 hours, the creature gains one level of {@condition exhaustion} and can repeat the saving throw if it can still see the fresco, ending the effect on a success. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the effect of the fresco for 24 hours. Destroying at least one 10-foot-square section of the fresco ends the effect for all creatures. Each 10-foot-square section has AC 17, 25 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: V4. Hall of Moradin
entries: This 20-foot-high hall has the following features:

items: Three pillars running the length of the hall are carved to resemble warhammers, with their square heads pressed against the floor.
The west wall bears a cracked mosaic that depicts a dwarf smith at a forge, crafting dwarves out of black metal and {@item diamond||diamonds}. (In the south end of the wall is a secret door.)
Three archways in the east wall lead to crumbling bridges that span the entrance foyer ({@area V2|23a}) and end in front of adamantine doors (leading to areas V6, V7, and V8).

entries.name: Black Pudding
entries: A little more than halfway down the hall, a section of the western mural has broken off, forming a heap of shattered tile on the floor. A crack in the wall conceals a {@creature black pudding} that gushes out and attacks characters who inspect the damage.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A character who searches the hall for secret doors and succeeds on a DC 17 Wisdom (Perception) check notices the outline of a secret door that leads to {@area V5|242}. The door opens automatically when a dwarf (or a creature transformed into a dwarf with an {@spell alter self} spell or similar magic) touches it; otherwise, a successful DC 17 Strength (Athletics) check is needed to push open the heavy door.

entries.name: V5. Secret Room
entries: This dust-filled room has lain untouched since the time of the Delzoun dwarves. Green copper urns on platforms overflow with coins, gems, and more.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: This room holds five copper urns (worth 25 gp each). Urn 1 contains five tourmalines (worth 100 gp each) mixed in with 200 cp. Urn 2 contains a {@item ring of warmth} mixed in with ten ordinary gold rings (worth 25 gp each) and 650 sp. Urn 3 is piled high with 250 gp. Urn 4 holds 33 blue quartz gemstones (worth 10 gp each). Urn 5 holds a 9-inch-tall silver statuette of a dwarf priest of Moradin with amethyst eyes (worth 250 gp and weighing 10 pounds).

entries.name: V6. Hammer and Anvil
entries: The adamantine door to this room has an {@spell arcane lock} spell cast on it, but it swings open when a dwarf or a creature transformed into a dwarf touches it. Another creature can force it open with a successful DC 21 Strength (Athletics) check. A {@spell knock} spell or similar magic also opens it. The door swings into the room on stiff adamantine hinges.

items: The north, east, and south walls of this 20-foot-high room are adorned with dust-covered frescoes depicting dwarf smiths at work in their forges.
An iron anvil sits atop a raised stone block in the middle of the floor. Both fixtures are draped in cobwebs.

entries.name: Frescoes
entries: A character who inspects the wall frescoes and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check notices that the stone hammer being wielded by the smith in the fresco on the south wall can be taken away from where it rests. When removed, it leaves a hammer-shaped indentation in the wall. Etched into the side of the hammer that was facing the wall is the following inscription in Dwarvish runes: "Let hearts be lifted and battles won." The hammer must be removed from its indentation for the inscription to be seen.

entries.name: Iron Anvil
entries: If the characters clear away the cobwebs, they see an inscription on the front of the stone block. Written in Dwarvish runes, it reads as follows: "Let the hammer fall and the anvil ring."

If the anvil is struck by the stone hammer that was taken from the wall, each creature in the room that can hear the anvil ring gains 10 temporary hit points that last for 24 hours. Once the anvil has bestowed this gift, it can't do so again for 24 hours.

entries.name: V7. Dumathoin's Secret
entries: This room is sealed by an adamantine door similar to the one in {@area V6|244}. The room contains the following features:

items: Four suits of rusted plate armor sans helmets, sized for a dwarf, stand in the corners of this 20-foot-high room. Each suit is draped in cobwebs.
Dwarvish runes are carved into the far wall. The inscription reads, "A secret never before told will part Dumathoin's lips."

entries: A successful DC 14 Intelligence (Religion) check identifies Dumathoin as the dwarven god of secrets. Any dwarf character automatically knows this.

entries.name: Secret Stair
entries: The engraving on the wall is a clue that this room holds a secret, specifically a trapdoor so well hidden that it can't be found by using magic or searching. But when any creature in the room speaks aloud a secret, the trapdoor flips open, giving access to a spiral stone staircase that descends 120 feet to {@area V9|24b}. The spoken admission must be true, and it must be something the character has not previously revealed.

entries.name: V8. Ol' Fire Eyes
entries: This room has the following features:

items: A 10-foot-tall painted statue of an armored male dwarf wielding a battleaxe and wearing a mask stands at the back of this 20-foot-high room.
Before the statue, set into the floor, is an adamantine trapdoor with a pull ring along one side.

entries.name: Trap
entries: A successful DC 17 Intelligence (Religion) check enables a character to recognize the statue as a depiction of Gorm Gulthyn, the dwarven god of vigilance also known as Fire Eyes. The statue melds seamlessly with the floor and can't be toppled. It also seems impervious to damage. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of evocation magic on the statue.

The trapdoor is false and can't be lifted. Anyone who touches the trapdoor or its pull ring must succeed on a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw or be struck by rays of magical fire that spring from the statue's eyes, dealing 22 ({@dice 4d10}) fire damage. The trap doesn't trigger if the target has total cover.

entries.name: V9. Main Vault
entries: When the characters arrive here for the first time, read:

Although deep underground, this vault is lit by streams of sunlight that pour down from the ceiling, catching motes of dust in their luminous pools. Ornate columns support a thirty-foot-high vaulted ceiling, which is adorned with carvings of dwarves basking in the presence of their gods. Deep alcoves line the walls, and piled in one of them is a vast golden trove.

Out of the dusty gloom steps an aged dwarf clutching a staff carved and painted to resemble a pair of entwined dragons-one red, one gold. Despite the dwarf's age, his eyes are steady and bright. "I wasn't expecting anyone," he says plainly. "As you can see, the place is a mess. Perhaps you should come back later, after I've tidied up a bit."

The dwarf, who calls himself Barok Clanghammer, is really the {@creature adult gold dragon} {@creature Aurinax|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) in disguise. He guards the gold for Lord Dagult Neverember and holds the {@item dragonstaff of Ahghairon|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDH|11}) in exchange for his services. Dealing with the gold dragon presents an unusual challenge for the characters, and a peaceful resolution is more likely to benefit them than a violent one.

{@creature Aurinax|WDH} is patient, wise, merciful, and vigilant. He remains in humanoid form until combat breaks out, since he can't easily carry the {@item dragonstaff of Ahghairon|WDH} in dragon form. The dragon attacks only in defense of itself, the staff, or the gold. The only individuals authorized to remove the gold under {@creature Aurinax|WDH}'s watch are Dagult Neverember and his appointed vassals, none of whom are currently in Waterdeep.

The characters can try to convince {@creature Aurinax|WDH} that they have come on Neverember's behalf. Since he has never met them before or heard Neverember mention them by name, {@creature Aurinax|WDH} is doubtful of their story. Fooling the dragon requires each character within his line of sight to succeed on a Charisma (Deception) check contested by the dragon's Wisdom (Insight) check. If even one character loses the contest, {@creature Aurinax|WDH} senses that the group is lying to him. These checks are made with advantage if {@creature Renaer Neverember|wdh} is with the party, since the dragon remembers meeting Renaer when he was but a child and can easily imagine a scenario in which Dagult Neverember might use his son as his vassal. (The dragon knows nothing of the animosity between Renaer and his father.)

The characters can try to convince the noble dragon that Lord Neverember embezzled the gold from the people of Waterdeep, and that it would be fair and just to see the coin safely returned to its rightful owners. Deep down, {@creature Aurinax|WDH} knows where the gold came from, but the dragon has allowed his greed and his agreement with Lord Neverember to cloud his moral judgment. With a successful DC 18 Charisma (Persuasion) check, a character can talk the dragon into allowing the gold to be returned to the people to whom it rightfully belongs. The check is made with advantage if the characters brought a prominent city official with them, such as {@creature Mirt|WDH} or {@creature Vajra Safahr|WDH}, or if one of the characters professes to be a worshiper of Bahamut.

Any Charisma (Intimidation) check made to influence {@creature Aurinax|WDH} automatically fails. After the first such attempt, all future Charisma checks made by the party to influence {@creature Aurinax|WDH} have disadvantage.

{@creature Aurinax|WDH} uses Legendary Resistance to avoid being {@condition charmed}. If a character tries to charm him with a spell and fails, all future Charisma checks made by the party to influence {@creature Aurinax|WDH} have disadvantage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Choose two alcoves in the vault. Piled in one alcove are 500,000 gp, the combined weight of which is 10,000 pounds. Scattered on the floor of the second alcove are sixty-five 100 gp gemstones-all that remains of {@creature Aurinax|WDH}'s current food supply.

{@creature Aurinax|WDH} won't give up his gemstones or the {@item dragonstaff of Ahghairon|WDH} willingly, since they are his payment for guarding the gold. If need be, however, the dragon is willing to use the staff's power on behalf of the city in exchange for more gemstones.

entries.name: Leaving the Vault
entries: As the characters leave the vault, with or without the gold, they are confronted by a hostile force sent by the main villain or villains. If the vault doors were left open, the characters encounter these antagonists in {@area V2|23a}; otherwise, they're lurking outside the vault, waiting for the characters to emerge:

items: If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is the main villain, {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) arrives with six {@creature bugbear||bugbears} and a {@creature gazer|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). If Noska is dead or otherwise indisposed, the beholder replaces him with {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) and his {@creature grell} bodyguard.

If the Cassalanters are the villains, they send three {@creature cult fanatic||cult fanatics} and three {@creature cultist||cultists}. Victoro's {@creature doppelganger} manservant, {@creature Willifort Crowelle|WDH}, leads the group in his tiefling guise unless the characters killed him or otherwise disposed of him earlier in this chapter or in chapter 6.

If {@creature Jarlaxle Baenre|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is the villain, he arrives with three {@creature drow gunslinger|WDH|drow gunslingers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). Replace no-name drow gunslingers with {@creature Fel'rekt Lafeen|WDH}, {@creature Krebbyg Masq'il'yr|WDH}, and {@creature Soluun Xibrindas|wdh} if they are alive and free.

If {@creature Manshoon|WDH} is the main villain, he sends his simulacrum (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) along with Agorn Fuoco (NE male Turami human {@creature bard|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), Vevette Blackwater (CE female Tethyrian human {@creature swashbuckler|VGM}; see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), and three Zhent {@creature thug||thugs}. If Agorn and Vevette were killed or otherwise disposed of earlier in this chapter or in chapter 8, replace each of them with one additional {@creature thug}.

entries: The forces sent by {@creature Xanathar|WDH}, the Cassalanters, and {@creature Manshoon|WDH} attack the characters on sight. Jarlaxle, on the other hand, congratulates characters for unlocking the Vault of Dragons and allows them to leave on the condition that they go empty-handed. He intends to see the gold safely returned to the city of Waterdeep but also demands the {@item dragonstaff of Ahghairon|WDH} for his trouble.

If {@creature Aurinax|WDH} is alive, the characters can lure enemies to the dragon. {@creature Aurinax|WDH} attacks any creature that attacks him or tries to steal his staff or the gold. He also defends the characters if he has made a deal with them.

entries.name: Faction Reinforcements
entries: If the characters joined one or more factions in Waterdeep and kept them informed of their progress, you can have reinforcements arrive to help combat the villains or introduce a new element to the situation.

entries.name: Bregan D'aerthe
entries: If {@creature Jarlaxle Baenre|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) isn't the main villain, he arrives with his lieutenants, {@creature Fel'rekt Lafeen|WDH}, {@creature Krebbyg Masq'il'yr|WDH}, and {@creature Soluun Xibrindas|wdh}, or three other {@creature drow gunslinger|WDH|drow gunslingers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). Jarlaxle offers to help the characters if they agree to help him secure the gold for Waterdeep and the {@item dragonstaff of Ahghairon|WDH} for himself.

entries.name: Harpers
entries: {@creature Mirt|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) arrives with two female human {@creature swashbuckler|VGM|swashbucklers} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). If he's still alive and not already with the characters, {@creature Renaer Neverember|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) replaces one of the swashbucklers.

entries.name: Emerald Enclave
entries: Jeryth Phaulkon sends three {@creature swarm of rats||swarms of rats} to assist the characters. Once the characters are no longer in peril, the rats disperse throughout the vault.

entries.name: Force Grey
entries: {@creature Vajra Safahr|WDH} sends {@creature Meloon Wardragon|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) to help the characters secure the vault, unaware that Meloon has fallen under {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s sway. If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is the main villain, Meloon helps the beholder's forces defeat the characters.

entries.name: Lords' Alliance
entries: Open Lord {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) arrives with {@creature Jalester Silvermane|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) and six City Guard {@creature veteran||veterans} to help characters secure the gold. Laeral's arrival forces Jarlaxle to be on his best behavior. After assuring Laeral of his good intentions, Jarlaxle cuts his losses and withdraws peacefully. If she is able to speak with {@creature Aurinax|WDH}, Laeral convinces the dragon to relinquish the gold into her custody.

entries.name: Order of the Gauntlet
entries: {@creature Hlam|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) arrives and aids the characters as best he can. He and {@creature Aurinax|WDH} met each other many years ago, and they are on fair speaking terms. {@creature Aurinax|WDH} is fond of the monk, and characters who negotiate with the dragon in {@creature Hlam|WDH}'s presence gain advantage on their Charisma (Persuasion) checks.

entries.name: Zhentarim
entries: The Doom Raiders (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) arrive to help secure the vault, less any members who have been arrested or killed. If {@creature Manshoon|WDH} is the main villain, {@creature Skeemo Weirdbottle|WDH} betrays his fellow Doom Raiders and fights alongside {@creature Manshoon|WDH}'s simulacrum. If they and the characters emerge victorious, the surviving Doom Raiders propose to split the take evenly with the characters. If the characters refuse this offer and the Doom Raiders outnumber them, the Zhents turn against them, putting characters who are Zhentarim members in a predicament.

entries.name: Adventure Conclusion
entries: The adventure could play out in any of several ways, depending on who gets the gold and what's done with the treasure.

entries.name: Dying in the Vault
entries: If the characters die in the Vault of Dragons with the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} and the main villain doesn't know the vault's location, the secrets of the vault die with them. Though they succumbed in the process, they succeeded in keeping the gold out of the villain's clutches-a bittersweet victory, indeed.

entries.name: Removing the Gold
entries: If the characters recover Neverember's hoard and keep it for themselves, word gets out eventually.

Emissaries of the Harpers, the Lords' Alliance, and the Order of the Gauntlet come to the characters, asking that the gold be returned to Waterdeep. If the characters refuse to give it up, they are stripped of any memberships they might hold in these factions and quickly find themselves in political hot water. The Lords of Waterdeep charge them with the crime of robbery against the citizens of the city. The characters face up to 1 month of hard labor plus damages equal to the value of the stolen currency plus 500 gp. If they try to flee the city, the City Guard apprehends and imprisons them. If they somehow evade the local authorities, the Harpers and agents of the Lords' Alliance pursue them tirelessly.

{@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH} is prepared to let the characters keep one-tenth of the treasure (50,000 gp) for themselves. Even that much coin attracts unwanted attention, in the form of several people who beg loans or donations from them:

items: {@creature Emmek Frewn|WDH} (see "Business Rival: {@creature Emmek Frewn|WDH}") needs 1,500 gp to pay off a loan with interest. If he doesn't repay the coin in a tenday, {@creature Istrid Horn|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) sends Zhentarim thugs to threaten, if not hurt, him. Emmek comes to the characters with hat in hand, preying on their generosity while denying any wrongdoing on his part.

{@creature Davil Starsong|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) asks the characters for a donation of 5,000 gp to keep his branch of the Zhentarim afloat in Waterdeep. Recent altercations and legal issues have drained the Doom Raiders' coffers. If the characters refuse, the Doom Raiders are driven out of the city, yielding control of the Zhentarim in Waterdeep to {@creature Manshoon|WDH} (if he's alive).

{@creature Floon Blagmaar|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) asks the characters to give him 500 gp to cover a hefty gambling debt. If the characters refuse to give Floon the gold, he vanishes without a trace {@dice 1d10} days later.

{@creature volothamp "volo" geddarm|ToA|Volothamp Geddarm} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) asks the characters for 5,000 gp to fund an expedition that he hopes will inspire a future book, for which he'll give them special mention in said masterwork. If the characters seem hesitant, Volo reminds them that were it not for his starting them off on this adventure, they wouldn't have the gold in the first place.

Jelenn Urmbrusk, a Masked Lord in debt to {@creature Manshoon|WDH}, requests an interest-free loan of 10,000 gp, which she vows to repay within a year. In exchange, she promises to use her "considerable influence with the Lords of Waterdeep" to help them in the future. If the characters oblige, she makes good on her promise to pay them back and grants them a special favor (see "Marks of Prestige" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg}). If they refuse, they will have made an enemy of the secret Masked Lord.
Temples, charities, guilds, and down-on-their-luck strangers come knocking from time to time. What they ask for isn't much-a few gold here and there-but it all adds up.

entries.name: Onward and Downward
entries: The characters should be 5th level by the end of this adventure. In the weeks that follow, word of their deeds spreads to every corner of Waterdeep. Finally, a note is delivered to them that reads as follows:
Undermountain beckons. See you at the Yawning Portal.
If the characters want to explore Undermountain, you can continue this campaign up through 20th level with the book {@i Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage}.

data.name: Spring Madness
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has let its paranoia get the better of it, and the beholder trusts no one. The {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH} disappeared from its lair while it was brokering a deal that would have merged the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild and the Zhentarim into a single criminal organization. Although the Zhents didn't steal the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} believes they did. Once content to merely possess the stone, the beholder is no longer confident of the gold's safety in the Vault of Dragons. {@creature Xanathar|WDH} thinks that the gold would be safer under its watchful gaze, but without the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, it can't remember where the gold is hidden.

Before running this chapter, review the "Beholders" section of the {@book Monster Manual|mm}, particularly the section titled "A Beholder's Lair." Within its lair, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has access to lair actions, and characters might encounter the beholder's regional effects as well.

Characters who don't visit {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair in the course of this adventure might have reason to do so in {@i Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage}. In that adventure, the characters are most likely to approach the beholder's lair from Skullport (see {@area X4|278} for details).

As they explore {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair, characters will see a recurring symbol that looks like a circle with ten equidistant spokes radiating out from its circumference. This symbol is {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s personal rune as well as the symbol used to represent the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild.

entries.name: Facing Xanathar
entries: Roll percentile dice to determine the beholder's location when the characters arrive, and consult the {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s Location table.

entries.caption: Xanathar's Location
rows: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is talking to {@creature Sylgar|wdh}, its pet fish, in {@area X19|29c}.
{@creature Xanathar|WDH} is delivering a rambling sermon to minions in the audience chamber ({@area X18|29a}).
{@creature Xanathar|WDH} is watching a fight in the Pit of Blood and Fortune ({@area X6|27a}).
{@creature Xanathar|WDH} is contemplating its mortality in the crypt, amid the remains of past Xanathars ({@area X33|2bf}).

entries: If the characters attack the beholder, it destroys one character and tries to subjugate the rest. In exchange for their lives, the survivors must agree to help the beholder find the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}. If they refuse, the beholder destroys another character and repeats the offer. This process continues until the characters comply or none are left. Those who agree to the beholder's terms are permitted to leave with their lives.

If the characters give {@creature Xanathar|WDH} the stone, it demands that they accompany it to the Vault of Dragons and help it defeat the vault's draconic guardian. Not fully trusting the characters to keep their part of the bargain, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} brings along its majordomo, {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH}, to keep an eye on them.

If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is reduced to half its maximum hit points, or if it believes its life to be in mortal danger, it activates its {@item ring of invisibility} and howls to {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} to "tear the usurpers limb from limb." While {@condition invisible}, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} flies to its sanctum ({@area X19|29c}) by the safest route.

{@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s greatest weakness is its insane love for its pet fish, {@creature Sylgar|wdh}. A character who uses the fish for leverage can make a DC 16 Charisma (Intimidation) check. On a success, the fearsome beholder becomes a blubbering mess and acquiesces to almost any request the character makes. On a failure, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} demands that the character release {@creature Sylgar|WDH} at once or be disintegrated (and makes good on its threat).

entries.name: Foiling Xanathar's Operation
entries: Killing the beholder is probably beyond the characters' capabilities, but they can sabotage its operation in several ways, affecting either the beholder personally or the smooth functioning of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild. They might even be able to marshal sufficient resources (including enough explosives) to bring down {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair.

entries.name: Enrage Xanathar
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s mental state is precarious. Whenever it flies into a rage, the beholder tends to kill random minions.

entries.name: Abduct or Kill Sylgar
entries: Killing or stealing {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s pet fish and preventing the fishkeeper, {@creature Ott Steeltoes|wdh}, from replacing it causes {@creature Xanathar|WDH} to become enraged.

entries.name: Destroy the Dream Nullifier
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s "dream nullifier" in {@area X20|2a2} gives it peace of mind and helps it sleep. Destroying this contraption makes the beholder unhappy.

entries.name: Take Its Food Away
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} eats meals prepared by the kobold chefs in {@area X30|2ba}. Killing these kobolds or otherwise preventing them from preparing meals makes {@creature Xanathar|WDH} furious.

entries.name: Disrupt Command
entries: Even though the beholder is the supreme leader of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild, its lieutenants manage the guild's day-to-day operations. The chain of command can be disrupted in any of the following ways.

entries.name: Assassination
entries: Killing one of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s most trusted underlings, such as {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} or {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh}, throws the day-to-day operation of the guild into chaos for a tenday.

entries.name: Blind Xanathar
entries: {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) has concocted a poison that can blind {@creature Xanathar|WDH} and throw the guild into chaos.

entries.name: Sow Mistrust
entries: If the beholder is tricked into believing there's a conspiracy to kill it or {@creature Sylgar|wdh}, it disintegrates the suspected conspirators, leaving gaping holes in the chain of command.

entries.name: Important Underlings
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} relies on underlings for advice, information, and day-to-day oversight of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild. The following important underlings are described in appendix B:

items: {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH}, dwarf majordomo
{@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh}, drow advisor
{@b Nihiloor}, {@creature mind flayer}
{@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh}, dwarf enforcer
{@creature Ott Steeltoes|wdh}, dwarf fishkeeper
{@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh}, dwarf engineer

entries.name: Destroy the Lair
entries: {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh} has smuggled smokepowder into the lair (see {@area X36|2cb}) and, with {@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh}'s help, identified areas that are structurally unstable. If these areas all suffer catastrophic damage, the lair collapses over the course of 1 hour. Characters can learn this information by speaking to Thorvin in {@area X13|28d}. The unstable areas are as follows:

items: {@area X2|273|u}, in the threshold of the secret door
{@area X6|27a|u}, at the top of the stone buttresses
{@area X17|297|u}, at the base of any three pillars
{@area X20|2a2|u}, against the back wall
{@area X22|2a5|u}, between the columns
{@area X30|2ba|u}, anywhere in the kitchen
{@area X33|2bf|u}, anywhere in the crypt

entries: As its lair collapses, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} uses its Disintegration Ray to carve an escape tunnel and flees to safety with minor injuries. It uses its Telekinetic Ray to transport its pet fish, {@creature Sylgar|wdh}, if it's within range. Underlings can flee with the beholder or through the tunnel to Skullport ({@area X4|278}). Those who can't accomplish either of these things are killed in the collapse.

entries.name: Xanathar's Lair
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair is an ancient dungeon complex originally built by Netherese wizards and expanded by beholders over time. It connects to the subterranean town of Skullport by way of a long tunnel ({@area X4|278}). A secret staircase ({@area X1|271}) gives access to Waterdeep's sewers.
The lair has the following features, with exceptions noted in the text:

items: Unless noted otherwise, rooms are 20 feet high and hallways are 15 feet high.
Rooms and corridors are brightly lit by {@spell continual flame} spells cast on wall sconces.

Most doors are single, circular slabs of stone, 8 feet in diameter and 6 inches thick, with stone hinges on one side. Double doors are 16-foot-wide, 8-foot-high semicircles that split open down the middle. Doorknobs are set into stone fixtures shaped like {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s symbol. ({@creature Xanathar|WDH} can open or close an unlocked door using its Telekinetic Ray, or obliterate a locked one with its Disintegration Ray.)

entries.name: Getting to the Lair
entries: Very few members of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild have access to the beholder's secret lair. If the characters want to get there, the following factions know where it is and can help them find it.

entries.name: Bregan D'aerthe
entries: Jarlaxle has a spy in the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild: the advisor {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh}, who uses {@spell sending} spells to transmit intelligence to his drow brethren. Bregan D'aerthe knows that the safest route to the beholder's lair is a secret staircase in the sewers of the Castle Ward. Any character who belongs to this faction can get this information from Jarlaxle or another source.

If the party includes at least one Bregan D'aerthe member with renown of 4 or more in the faction, four male {@creature drow} are waiting for the party at the top of the staircase. Their names are Arannis Nur'zekk, Beldar Tlabbath, Rylvar Tlabbath, and Draknafein Uriss. Their orders are to help the characters complete their mission, whatever the cost. These drow also have secret orders to kill {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh}, if he's still alive, and retrieve Jarlaxle's bag of holding (see {@area X35|2c7}). If you're tracking experience points, each drow gets an equal share of the XP while a member of the adventuring party.

entries.name: Harpers
entries: Characters who belong to the Harpers can approach {@creature Mirt|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), who knows the location of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair. (He has dealt with the beholder many times as a Lord of Waterdeep.)

{@creature Mirt|WDH} leads the characters to a secret staircase in the Castle Ward sewers ({@area X1|271}). As the characters prepare to descend the stairs, {@creature Mirt|WDH} tells them that {@creature Xanathar|WDH} doesn't relate well to humanoids, doesn't trust them as a matter of course, and is prone to imagining conspiracies where none exist. He also tells the characters that {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has a pet fish and is insanely protective of it.

{@creature Mirt|WDH} won't accompany the adventurers, but he knows a secret that could be helpful: {@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh}, {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s chief engineer, is a Harper informant. {@creature Mirt|WDH} shares this secret with any character who has renown of 4 or higher in the Harper faction.

entries.name: Lords' Alliance
entries: Characters who are members of the Lords' Alliance can reach out to {@creature Jalester Silvermane|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}). Jalester doesn't know the location of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair but can get the details from {@creature Laeral Silverhand|WDH}.

With the information in hand, Jalester leads the party to a secret staircase in the Castle Ward sewers ({@area X1|271}). As the characters prepare to descend the stairs, Jalester warns them to avoid confronting the paranoid and unpredictable beholder.

If one or more characters have renown of 4 or higher in the Lords' Alliance, Jalester offers to join the party on its mission into {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair. If you're tracking experience points, Jalester gets an equal share of the XP while a member of the adventuring party.

entries.name: Emerald Enclave
entries: Characters who are members of the Emerald Enclave can learn the location of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair by speaking with Jeryth Phaulkon at Phaulkonmere. Jeryth tells them that she has been sending {@creature awakened rat|wdh|awakened rats} into the sewers to find the beholder's lair, and that they recently discovered a secret staircase in the Castle Ward sewers leading down to it ({@area X1|271}). She has one of the awakened rats lead them there. This {@creature rat} has an Intelligence score of 10 and can speak Common.

entries.name: Zhentarim
entries: Characters who are members of the Zhentarim can approach {@creature Yagra Stonefist|wdh} at the Yawning Portal (see "Familiar Faces"). She recently learned about a "back door" to the beholder's lair from a drunken blabbermouth with ties to the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild. Yagra offers to lead them to a secret staircase in the sewers under the Castle Ward ({@area X1|271}). "Trust me," she says, "it's safer than the route through Undermountain and Skullport."

Yagra will join their descent if the characters promise to pay her at least 1,000 gp. Otherwise, she wishes them well and heads back to the Yawning Portal. If you're tracking experience points, Yagra gets an equal share of the XP while a member of the adventuring party.

entries.name: Areas of the Lair
entries: The following areas correspond to the labels on map 5.1. This lair has two levels connected by staircases and secret doors.

entries.name: X1. Staircase of Eyes
entries: Characters are most likely to enter {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair by this route: a spiral staircase accessible from the Castle Ward's sewers and hidden behind a secret door. This staircase circumvents a more difficult route through Undermountain and Skullport, which is described in {@i Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage}.
When the characters find the staircase, read:
The walls of this narrow, spiraling staircase are carved with opened eyes that glow with a faint, magical light.

Characters feel as though they're being watched as they descend the stairs, and the feeling doesn't go away once they enter the beholder's lair. The dimly lit staircase descends for hundreds of feet, ending before a circular stone door that swings open into {@area X2|273}.

entries.name: X2. Watched Hall
entries: This magically lit hall has the following features:

items: The walls are carved with eyes of all shapes and sizes. Many of the orbs have stone eyelids that open and close at irregular intervals.
Characters who succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check notice a ghostly eyestalk (scrying sensor) protruding from the ceiling directly in front of the double door to the south.
A secret door is hidden in the west wall.

entries.name: Blinking Eyes
entries: The blinking eye carvings are slightly unnerving but harmless.

entries.name: Scrying Sensor
entries: The ghostly eyestalk is a magical sensor that allows one of the apprentice wizards in {@area X16|292} to monitor this hall. The eyestalk functions as an extra eye with darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. A character can ascertain the eyestalk's function with a successful DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana) check but can't determine who's peering through it, or from where. The eyestalk can't be damaged but is destroyed by a {@spell dispel magic} spell. The sensor is suppressed within the area of an antimagic field.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door can be found with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. To open it, one must press a nearby wall carving shaped like an eye. When this is done, the secret door swings inward, revealing a curved hallway ({@area X8|27f}) beyond.

entries.name: X3. Beholder Zombie Guard
entries: A {@creature beholder zombie} guards this magically lit room. Surrounding it are four {@creature gas spore||gas spores}, which look like immature beholders at first glance. All five creatures float in the middle of the room.

The beholder zombie is all that remains of a beholder that arose from the Underdark to challenge {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s supremacy. After defeating its rival, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} had the corpse animated and transformed into a lair guardian. The gas spores were added later.

The beholder zombie allows creatures that brandish the symbol of {@creature Xanathar|WDH} to pass unmolested. Otherwise, it attacks. The gas spores don't attack but explode if they take any damage. The beholder zombie is immune to their Death Burst trait.

entries.name: X4. Tunnel to Skullport
entries: This magically lit tunnel extends 300 feet eastward off the map. It ends at a staircase that climbs 20 feet to the Guts & Garters Inn, an establishment located in the subterranean town of Skullport, which is under {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s control. See {@i Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage} for more information on the inn and Skullport.

entries.name: X5. Horror's Alcove
entries: A suit of {@creature animated armor} with {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s symbol embossed on its breastplate stands in this alcove, appearing at a glance to be an ornate but inanimate suit of armor on display. It remains inert until it takes damage or is summoned to {@area X6|27a} by {@creature Xanathar|WDH}. (The beholder uses it to keep the spectators in the arena from getting too rowdy.)

entries.name: X6. Pit of Blood and Fortune
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has turned this room into a gladiatorial arena. It also uses this location to dispose of underlings it no longer trusts in a manner that it considers entertaining.
This area has the following features:

items: A magically lit, circular chamber has a thin layer of blood-soaked sand covering the floor and stone buttresses supporting its 40-foot-high domed ceiling.

Ten-foot-high stone bleachers hug the northwest half of the room. Staircases lead from the bleachers to other areas of the lair, and a tunnel under the bleachers leads west to the monster cell block ({@area X7|27e}).

A semicircular recess in the southeast wall has steps leading up to it. Its floor is 5 feet higher than the arena floor, and the alcove is decorated with bouquets of Underdark fungi in stone vases and purple tapestries that bear {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s symbol. Jutting from the curved roof of the alcove is a spectral eyestalk (scrying sensor).
A secret door is hidden in the south wall.

entries: If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is elsewhere, the arena is empty but under surveillance (see "Scrying Sensor" below).

If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is present, it hovers in the southeast alcove and uses its {@item ring of invisibility} to remain unseen. Standing on the steps of the alcove are two dwarves: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s majordomo, {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), who presides over fight tournaments, and {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s chief enforcer, {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), who releases arena combatants from {@area X7|27e}. Ten human {@creature bandit||bandits} and five {@creature bugbear||bugbears} (all members of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild) guzzle ale and heckle combatants from the bleachers, while two {@creature goblin||goblins} serve up salted rat intestines and stirge meat pies.

entries.name: Joining a Tournament
entries: If the characters enter during a tournament, they see a {@creature minotaur} battling a scarred female halfling, {@creature Samara Strongbones|WDH} (see {@area X7|27e}). The halfling doesn't want to die in a pointless battle and screams for help. If the characters intervene, the arena spectators turn violent and attack them. If the characters let the fight play out, Noska escorts the victor back to {@area X7|27e} while {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} goads characters into joining the tournament. If the characters aren't willing to enter the tournament, {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} has them beaten {@condition unconscious} and locked up while {@creature Xanathar|WDH} watches silently.

Rules for running a tournament are described at the end of this chapter (see "Blood and Fortune"). If a character joins the tournament and wins, or defeats its underlings, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is impressed enough to grant the party an audience, during which it tries to subjugate them (see "{@area Facing Xanathar|25d|x}").

entries.name: Scrying Sensor
entries: The spectral eyestalk is a magical sensor, which allows an apprentice wizard in {@area X16|292} to monitor this room. See {@area X2|273} for more information.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door in the south wall can be found with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. It pushes open to reveal {@area X33|2bf} beyond.

entries.name: X7. Cell Block
entries: This area contains four cells separated by bars. The rectangular iron doors have locks built into them, and {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh} carries the keys. Picking a lock requires a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. Breaking down a cell door requires a successful DC 25 Strength (Athletics) check. The Cell Occupants table lists this area's prisoners.

entries.caption: Cell Occupants
rows: A male half-ogre named Groz, a minotaur named Umpok, and a female orog named Charworl

Kidnapped Waterdavians: Xia Shung (NG female Shou human bard see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), Claudio Benzreck (LN male Tethyrian human noble), and Arthright Grayfalcon (CN male Illuskan swashbuckler see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12})
A female drow named Raelyn Auvryndar, recently separated from her companion and subordinate, Zaibon Kyszalt (see {@area X24|2ab})

{@creature Samara Strongbones|WDH}, a female lightfoot halfling, is a Zhentarim spy in league with {@creature Manshoon|WDH}. She is chaotic evil and has these racial traits: She is Small, and her walking speed is 25 feet. She can move through the space of any Medium or larger creature. She has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}. She speaks Common, Halfling, and Undercommon.

entries.name: X8. Hall of Statues
entries: This 20-foot-wide, magically lit hallway connects various areas controlled by the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild. It has the following features:

items: Lifelike humanoid statues dot the hall.
The first time the characters explore the hall, a {@creature deep gnome (svirfneblin)||deep gnome} in clownish garb is dancing and cartwheeling up and down the hall, between the statues.

entries.name: Gnome Clown
entries: The garishly dressed deep gnome, Flutterfoot Zipswiggle, serves {@creature Xanathar|WDH} as a jester. He carries a packet containing {@item dust of disappearance}. Unknown to Flutterfoot, the beholder has tired of the gnome and plans to turn him to stone when next they meet.

Flutterfoot knows the features and layout of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair, as well as the beholder's current whereabouts and the locations of secret doors, except the ones leading to {@area X36|2cb}. He gleefully offers to serve as a guide if the characters correctly answer the following riddle:
I come with a smile;
In slaughter, I rest;
I can be contagious,
But my medicine is best.
What am I?
The answer to Flutterfoot's riddle is "laughter." If the characters give the wrong answer, the gnome sprinkles himself with {@item dust of disappearance}, turns {@condition invisible}, and flees.

entries.name: Lifelike Statues
entries: The statues are the {@condition petrified} remains of intruders and {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild members that were turned to stone by {@creature Xanathar|WDH}. There are a dozen statues in all: four humans, three goblins, two drow, a dwarf, a halfling, and a tiefling.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door to {@area X2|273} is clearly visible from this side. It is opened by turning a stone knob on the adjacent wall.

entries.name: X9. Guild Barracks
entries: This magically lit room has the following features:

items: The walls are covered with lewd graffiti written in Common, Dwarvish, {@creature Goblin}, and Undercommon.
In the front of the room is a ramshackle wooden table surrounded by empty barrels and casks that serve as stools. Drained tankards are strewn across the tabletop and the floor.
A dozen moldy bunk beds are arranged in two rows at the back of the room.

entries.name: Xanathar Guild Members
entries: When they're not watching a tournament in the arena ({@area X6|27a}) or listening to {@creature Xanathar|WDH} give a speech in the audience chamber ({@area X18|29a}), ten human {@creature bandit||bandits}, members of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild, sleep here. They're so drunk that, for the next few hours, they awaken only if they take damage. Also, they are {@condition poisoned} while they remain intoxicated.

entries.name: X10. Noska's Quarters
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s enforcer, {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), resides in this magically lit room when he's not in the arena ({@area X6|27a}). The room contains the following features:

items: A marble bathtub with clawed feet rests in the middle of the room, next to a large wooden cage containing a {@creature rust monster}. Along the walls are piles of broken and rusted helmets, {@item shield|PHB|shields}, and weapons.
Hanging from hooks on the back wall are three mannequins made of straw and canvas, with a multitude of crossbow bolts sticking in them.

entries: Noska keeps the rust monster as a pet and feeds it items from the piles of discarded helms, {@item shield|PHB|shields}, and armaments. He uses the mannequins for target practice. The bathtub, which he has converted into a bed, is padded with straw and mangy furs.

entries.name: Wooden Cage
entries: A simple latch holds the cage door shut. The rust monster can't harm anyone while trapped inside.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hidden under a pile of rusty weapons is a wooden chest containing Noska's personal hoard: 37 gp, 151 sp, 360 cp, and four bloodstones (worth 50 gp each).

entries.name: X11. Ahmaergo's Collection
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s majordomo fetishizes minotaurs and has decorated this magically lit room accordingly:

items: A stuffed, glowering minotaur stands at the north end of the room. A large greataxe rests on a wooden rack in front of it.
In the middle of the room is a 10-foot-long, 5-footwide, 3-foot-high rectangular slab of stone with a hand-carved, miniature model of a stone maze atop it.

entries.name: Stone Maze
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of conjuration magic around the model maze. A creature that touches the maze becomes the target of a {@spell maze} spell (save DC 15). Once the effect triggers, it can't do so again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Stuffed Minotaur
entries: When someone other than {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} opens the southern door, the skeleton of the stuffed minotaur erupts out of its skin, becoming an animated {@creature minotaur skeleton}, and arms itself with the greataxe. It attacks all intruders, pursuing any who flee into {@area X8|27f} or X12. The minotaur skeleton obeys {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH}'s commands.

entries.name: X12. Ahmaergo's Quarters
entries: The magical lights in this room have been dispelled, rendering the chamber dark. Characters who have a light source or darkvision can discern the following features:

items: The room has been converted into a maze, its walls made of stacked crates nailed together with boards. The walls rise to meet the 20-foot-high ceiling.
Humanoid bones litter the floor. ({@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} gathered the bones from Undermountain and put them here as grisly decorations.)

entries: The maze fills the entire room but for a 10-foot-square area in the southwest corner, where {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} keeps a wooden chest and a bed made from the skulls, bones, hide, and fur of minotaurs.

Getting through the maze takes time but isn't difficult, except that {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} has rigged a tripwire halfway through. A character in the lead who is searching for traps spots the tripwire with a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check. Once spotted, it can easily be avoided or disarmed. If the trap is triggered, the walls of the maze come crashing down. Every creature in the collapsing maze is hit by debris and must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@dice 3d6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH}'s chest contains 121 gp in a sack made of stitched flesh, a carved malachite figurine of a minotaur (worth 250 gp), and a {@item potion of healing}.

entries.name: X13. Thorvin's Workshop
entries: Double doors swing open into a magically lit chamber containing the following:

items: {@creature Thorvin Twinbeard|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s engineer, is building a large contraption in the middle of the room. Floating nearby is an albino {@creature gazer|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}).
Tools cover stone tables throughout the room. (There are enough tools here to assemble two sets of mason's tools, one set of smith's tools, and two sets of tinker's tools.)
Other furnishings include a cot and a stack of wooden casks filled with Wyrmwizz Ale (a Skullport brew).

entries.name: Albino Gazer
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} dreamed this gazer into existence and sent it to spy on Thorvin, whose loyalty the beholder is beginning to question. The gazer is itself disloyal. A wizard character can befriend it with a successful DC 11 Charisma (Persuasion) check and turn it into their familiar with a {@spell find familiar} ritual. When the gazer becomes a familiar, its alignment changes to match that of its new master.

entries.name: Thorvin Twinbeard
entries: When it is finished, Thorvin's contraption will enable {@creature Xanathar|WDH} to pulverize creatures that it petrifies, turning them into a fine powder that can be used to make plaster. The pulverizer consists mainly of a tall stone bin with grinding gears at the bottom, and a chute where the powdered stone pours out.

The pulverizer is a pet project of Thorvin's that allows him to hang around {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair and gather information, which he sells to the Harpers. (Thorvin puts the coin he earns from the faction in a bank, far from the beholder's prying eyes.) If one or more characters approach him and claim to be Harpers, Thorvin is upset that they would risk exposing him as a spy, pointing to the albino gazer. If the characters befriend the gazer and promise to go away, Thorvin truthfully answers as many as three questions. He's never seen {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH}'s chambers (areas X11 and X12) but knows the rest of the lair well.

If the characters are looking for a way to mess with {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s operation, Thorvin suggests they coerce {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh}, the beholder's advisor (see {@area X18|29a}), into giving them the large supply of {@item smokepowder|WDH} that he smuggled into the dungeon. Thorvin also tells them where to plant the {@item smokepowder|WDH} to cause the most damage (see "Destroy the Lair").

entries.name: X14. Secret Hallway
entries: This magically lit hall is concealed behind secret doors. It circumvents the audience chamber ({@area X18|29a}) and gently slopes down toward the east. Finding either secret door requires a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check.

entries.name: X15. Stairs to the Maze
entries: Characters at the top of these magically lit stairs can hear loud music and raucous laughter boiling up from below. The staircase descends 20 feet to {@area X28|2b5}.

entries.name: X16. Panopticus Guard Station
entries: This room contains the following features:

items: Five bald {@creature Panopticus Wizard|wdh|shield dwarves}, their heads covered with purple eye tattoos, sit around the edge of a glowing circle on the floor. Their eyes are scrunched shut, but they are aware of their surroundings.
Protruding from the ceiling, directly above the circle, is a large, flaring bronze "bell" similar in shape to the mouth of a tuba.
Set into the back of a recessed wall is a secret door that leads to {@area X17|297}.

entries.name: Dwarves
entries: The five {@creature Panopticus Wizard|wdh|tattooed dwarves} operate {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s "panopticus" magical surveillance system. They fight only in self-defense. They are {@creature apprentice wizard|VGM|apprentice wizards} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), with these changes:

items: They are neutral.

They have these racial traits: Their walking speed is 25 feet. They have advantage on saving throws against poison and resistance to poison damage. They have darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. They speak Common and Dwarvish.
{@creature Nihiloor|WDH} the mind flayer has psychically and surgically altered the dwarves so that they sleep with one eye open and half their brains asleep at any time.

entries.name: Amplification Bell
entries: The bronze bell is connected to a tube that runs through the stone and into the nearby audience chamber ({@area X18|29a}). The bell amplifies sounds underneath it and transmits those sounds to the audience chamber.

entries.name: Scrying Circle
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of divination magic around the circle, which the dwarves use to scry on various other locations within the dungeon: the entrance hall ({@area X2|273}), the arena ({@area X6|27a}), the antechamber of madness ({@area X23|2a6}), the recreation hall ({@area X28|2b5}), and the downstairs hall ({@area X32|2be}). One dwarf watches each location and communicates what it sees via the bronze bell. The scrying circle functions for no one else. It is suppressed within an {@spell antimagic field} and can also be dispelled (DC 17). When the circle ceases to exist, the ghostly eyestalk sensors in the above-mentioned locations disappear as well.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door can be spotted with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. A pedal hidden in the floor, when stepped on, causes the door to swing inward.

entries.name: X17. Promenade
entries: Pillars carved with eyes follow the curvature of the hall, and these eyes seem to track creatures as they pass by. This isn't a magical effect but an optical illusion.

entries.name: Majordomo
entries: If he's not with {@creature Xanathar|WDH} in the arena ({@area X6|27a}), {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is conducting a routine inspection of the dungeon. The characters can hear the dwarf's echoing footfalls as he approaches their location. If he sees intruders and is outnumbered, {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} retreats to {@area X22|2a5}, heads downstairs to gather reinforcements from {@area X28|2b5}, and leads a search party to capture the interlopers. If he sees only one intruder, he draws his axe and attacks.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The northernmost end of this hallway displays a fresco of a leafless tree that has lidless eyes embedded in its branches. Pressing a specific eye causes a door-shaped section of the wall to swing open into {@area X16|292}. Characters can find the secret door and the switch with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check.

entries.name: X18. Audience Chamber
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} greets visitors and makes speeches to its minions in this 40-foot-high domed chamber. Characters who were seen by the scrying sensors anywhere in the dungeon complex can't surprise the creatures here. The magically lit room contains the following features:

items: The circular floor is tiled in black marble and bears a gold mosaic of {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s symbol.
Jutting from the ceiling is a bronze, bell-shaped protuberance. (This fixture is the other end of the sound amplifier described in {@area X16|292}.)
Displayed against the curved walls are a dozen lifelike statues (the remains of humans, drow, dwarves, goblinoids, and kobolds who defied the beholder).
Hidden in the floor is a secret trapdoor.

entries: While in this room, {@creature Xanathar|WDH} uses its {@item ring of invisibility} to remain unseen and can use a bonus action to activate or deactivate a psychedelic display of magical lights, each one the size of a human eyeball. The lights fill a 10-foot cube in the middle of the room, and the beholder can throw its voice so that it seems to emanate from the same area. Any character who succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom (Insight) check can tell that the display isn't the source of the voice.

If the beholder is here, it's using the psychedelic light display to deliver an incoherent, self-aggrandizing speech to a group of sycophantic underlings consisting of ten human {@creature bandit||bandits} and two {@creature duergar} who have never seen {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s true form. These minions clutch tankards of Wyrmwizz Ale (a cheap Skullport brew) and toast {@creature Xanathar|WDH} whenever the beholder commends itself. {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s treacherous {@creature drow mage} advisor, {@creature Nar'l Xibrindas|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}), stands in front of the open door to {@area X19|29c}, clapping weakly at the speech. Floating next to Nar'l is his {@creature grell} bodyguard. If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has been warned that the characters are near, it wraps up its speech and grants them an audience; see "Facing {@creature Xanathar|WDH}," for more information.

If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is elsewhere, this room contains only Nar'l and the grell. Nar'l tries to lure adventurers into a showdown with the beholder. If he is wounded, he flees through the trapdoor in the floor and retreats to {@area X35|2c7} while the grell covers his escape.

If the party includes members of Bregan D'aerthe and Nar'l recognizes them as such, he gives them his vial of eyescratch poison so they can blind {@creature Xanathar|WDH} with it. This act of treachery, witnessed by the grell, turns the creature against him.

entries.name: Secret Trapdoor
entries: A hidden trapdoor in the floor can be found with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. It can be lifted with a successful DC 12 Strength (Athletics) check, revealing a wooden ladder that leads down to {@area X29|2b9}.

entries.name: X19. Xanathar's Sanctum
entries: This magically lit room has a flat, 30-foot-high ceiling and contains several features:

items: Luminous violet particles drift through the air like mist. A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Nature) check reveals that these are Underdark spores.
A 20-foot-diameter fishbowl dominates the room. Filled with water, it also contains a small coral reef, a miniature shipwreck, and a sunken treasure chest.

A smaller fishbowl, 3 feet in diameter, rests on a pedestal next to the larger bowl. A dwarf wearing a skullcap adorned with eyestalks feeds a trout-sized fish that swims in circles in this smaller bowl.
A 10-foot-diameter silver mirror is embedded in the western wall. Letters are engraved into its frame.
The eastern tunnel starts 10 feet above the floor and gently slopes upward to {@area X21|2a4}. ({@creature Xanathar|WDH} uses this passage as an escape route.)

entries: If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is here, it's {@condition invisible} and speaking affectionately to the fish while the dwarf, {@creature Ott Steeltoes|wdh}, feeds it.

entries.name: Dwarf Fishkeeper
entries: {@creature Ott Steeltoes|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s fishkeeper. If he sees intruders and the beholder isn't present, Ott draws his dagger and stammers, "You shouldn't be here! Stay back, or I'll call the boss!" Ott can't telepathically communicate with {@creature Xanathar|WDH}, but he thinks he can. He closes his eyes and frantically asks for {@creature Xanathar|WDH} to return to its sanctum and disintegrate the intruders.

entries.name: Fishbowls
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s pet fish, {@creature Sylgar|wdh}, is the only creature that the beholder loves as much as itself. In fact, there have been many Sylgars over the years, but Ott is skilled at acquiring a replacement before {@creature Xanathar|WDH} realizes its beloved pet has died.

{@creature Sylgar|WDH}'s large fishbowl weighs about 6,000 pounds, and the treasure chest at the bottom is real (see "Treasure" below). The small fishbowl weighs 60 pounds and is used primarily for feedings. {@creature Xanathar|WDH} uses its telekinesis ray to transfer {@creature Sylgar|WDH} from one fishbowl to another.

entries.name: Mirror
entries: Carved into the mirror's frame is the word "Xoblob." A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of divination magic around the mirror. Speaking the word "Xoblob" within 10 feet of the mirror causes its reflective surface to become a scrying sensor, showing the Old Xoblob Shop and the street in front of it, as seen through the eyes of the stuffed beholder that hangs in the shop's display window (see "Old Xoblob Shop").

entries.name: Spores
entries: The purple spores are infused with {@i faerzress}, a magical radiation found in the Underdark. A creature that ends its turn in the room must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or suffer a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the Short-Term Madness table in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg}. A creature doesn't need to inhale the spores to be affected by them. Once the madness ends, the creature becomes immune to the spores in this room.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The treasure chest is unlocked and contains thirty 100 gp gemstones. If {@creature Xanathar|WDH} has retrieved the {@item Stone of Golorr|WDH}, the artifact is also here.

entries.name: X20. Dream Nullifier
entries: This side chamber contains the following features:

items: A 6-foot-diameter bowl made of crystal lattice pulsates with multicolored light as it floats 10 feet off the floor.
A mangy straw pallet lies on the floor under the bowl. (The fishkeeper, {@creature Ott Steeltoes|wdh}, uses the pallet as a bed.)

entries.name: Dream Nullifier
entries: {@creature Xanathar|WDH} hired a wizard to construct a device that would prevent it from accidentally dreaming another beholder into existence. The bowl-shaped "dream nullifier" magically wakes {@creature Xanathar|WDH} when it starts to dream about other beholders. If the bowl is engulfed by an {@spell antimagic field} or targeted by a {@spell dispel magic} spell or similar effect, it crashes to the floor and shatters into a million pieces.

entries.name: X21. Beholder Escape Route
entries: Set into the floor at the north end of a tunnel that gently slopes down to {@area X19|29c} is a circular stone plug that opens in the ceiling of the hallway below. {@creature Xanathar|WDH} can lift the plug with its telekinesis ray, creating an opening just large enough for it to float through. A character can lift the stone plug with a successful DC 19 Strength (Athletics) check.

entries.name: X22. Arrival Point
entries: Any creature holding the correct key that steps through the magical portal in {@area Q11|089} of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild hideout (see chapter 1) appears here, between the columns of rock.
A curling staircase in the southwest corner descends 20 feet to {@area X32|2be}.

entries.name: X23. Antechamber of Madness
entries: This great hall has the following features:

items: A {@creature kuo-toa whip} and six {@creature kuo-toa} guard the hall. They gather in front of an iron portcullis in the southeast corner and tear bits of flesh off the bones of a recently slain dwarf.
A ghostly eyestalk protrudes from the ceiling in the middle of the hall.
The floor is littered with bones and covered with a thin layer of sticky, translucent slime.

entries.name: Kuo-toa
entries: These insane creatures are under the control of the mind flayer in {@area X24|2ab} and obey its telepathic commands to the best of their ability. When they detect intruders, they cry out, "Ooop! Ooop!" to alert their illithid master, then charge into battle.

entries.name: Portcullis
entries: The portcullis between this area and {@area X24|2ab} can be raised with a successful DC 22 Strength (Athletics) check, or with a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic. The lever to raise the portcullis is in {@area X24|2ab}.

entries.name: Scrying Sensor
entries: The ghostly eyestalk is a magical sensor that allows one of the apprentice wizards in {@area X16|292} to monitor this room. See {@area X2|273} for more information.

entries.name: Sticky Slime
entries: The slime-covered floor is {@quickref difficult terrain||3} for all creatures except kuo-toa, other creatures that have the Slippery trait, and creatures that fly.

entries.name: X24. Extraction Chamber
entries: A portcullis separates this room from {@area X23|2a6}, and the lever to raise and lower it is set into the north wall. Characters who peer through the bars of the portcullis can see the room's contents:

items: In the middle of the room, a blood-spattered chair made of carved stone stands atop a 10-foot-square, 1-foot-high stone slab. Iron manacles are bolted to the chair's armrests.
Trapped in the chair is a {@condition stunned} and weaponless male {@creature drow} in a chain shirt. He is trying to free himself of his bonds but is making no progress.

entries.name: Drow Captive
entries: The drow, Zaibon Kyszalt, was captured in Skullport and brought here for interrogation. His superior, Raelyn Auvryndar, was also captured and is confined in {@area X7|27e}. Zaibon wants to free her and escape into Undermountain, where House Auvryndar has outposts.

{@creature Nihiloor|WDH} has a key that unlocks the chair's shackles. A character can unlock each shackle with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, and a creature shackled to the chair can slip free of these bonds with a successful DC 25 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check.

The mind flayer has telepathically interrogated Zaibon and learned about a House Auvryndar plot to conquer Skullport, as well as mounting tensions between the drow houses of Auvryndar and Freth. The mind flayer is getting ready to implant an intellect devourer in Zaibon's skull, then use him to undermine the drow plot and foment war between the drow houses. (Were Zaibon less useful, the mind flayer would have extracted his brain and turned it into an intellect devourer instead.) Zaibon knows nothing of the fate that awaits him.

entries.name: Mind Flayer
entries: If the characters haven't already dealt with {@creature Nihiloor|WDH}, the mind flayer interrupts as they interact with Zaibon, entering from {@area X26|2b1} with an {@creature intellect devourer} in its hands. If Zaibon is free of the chair, he tries to get as far away from the mind flayer and its "pet" as he can. {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} doesn't pursue anyone who flees, trusting that they won't get far.

entries.name: Replacing the Mind Flayer
entries: {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} the mind flayer has carved out its own lair within {@creature Xanathar|WDH}'s lair (areas X23 through X26). If {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} is killed earlier in the adventure, replace it with a mind flayer named Qrr'zarq.

Qrr'zarq comes from a colony of mind flayers in Undermountain that wants to implant {@creature Xanathar|WDH} with an illithid tadpole and, through a magical process called ceremorphosis, turn the beholder into a thrall. Qrr'zarq is waiting for an opportunity to implant the tadpole while {@creature Xanathar|WDH} is alone and asleep. The mind flayer doesn't want adventurers to complicate or ruin its brilliant plan, which it keeps to itself. It offers to help characters who agree not to harm it or the beholder.

entries.name: X25. Food for Thought
entries: This magically lit room contains these features:

items: The room reeks of death and carnage.
Three wooden tables are arranged corner to corner, forming a triangle, in the middle of the room. The floor around them is stained with blood.

Atop two of the tables, held down with leather straps, are two humans ({@creature commoner||commoners}) dressed like homeless men. One looks dead, and the other gibbers like a madman. The third table is bare except for an area of sticky blood at one end.

entries.name: Unhappy Meals
entries: The {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild captures homeless Waterdavians and brings them here for {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} to feed on. After devouring their brains, the mind flayer gives their corpses to his kuo-toa thralls to eat.

The two men, a locksmith named Skarn Zarphoul and a broadcrier named Holvan Ebberek, recently heard a dwarf getting his brain sucked out. Skarn is {@condition stunned} and catatonic from the shock of it, and Holvan is a gibbering lunatic. A {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic restores either man's sanity. The men were hooded and brought here separately, so they know nothing of the dungeon's layout or occupants (other than the mind flayer). If their sanity is restored, they are eager to return to their families in Waterdeep.

entries.name: X26. Devourer Spawning Pool
entries: This room has the following features:

items: In the middle of the area is a 10-foot-diameter, 2-foot-deep circular pool containing luminous green brine. Swimming in the brine are four {@creature intellect devourer||intellect devourers}. If it has not been encountered and defeated elsewhere, {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} the {@creature mind flayer} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is standing in the pool with the intellect devourers.
Rusty manacles are bolted to the walls. (Hosts for the intellect devourers are chained in these locations.)

entries: The brine is a magical substance that radiates an aura of transmutation magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell. {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} uses it to transform humanoid brains into intellect devourers. The process is far from perfect. A full 90 percent of the brains left in the brine rot and die, while the remaining 10 percent transform after marinating for {@dice 1d4 + 1} days.
{@creature Nihiloor|WDH} and the intellect devourers make their stand here. If the characters flee, the mind flayer sends the intellect devourers after them and stays behind.

entries.name: X27. Prison
entries: {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} the mind flayer uses this prison to confine potential hosts for his brood of intellect devourers. Captured characters might find themselves incarcerated here until they can be made into hosts. The area contains the following features:

items: Eight locked iron doors lead to cells, some of which have bars separating them.

Three {@creature kuo-toa whip||kuo-toa whips} stand guard here and attack any creature other than {@creature Nihiloor|WDH} that enters, including other kuo-toa. One of the whips carries the keys to the cell doors on a ring.
A 1-foot-tall figurine of an otherworldly creature rests atop a slime-covered alabaster pedestal against the east wall, between two cell doors.

entries.name: Cells
entries: A character outside a cell can pick its lock with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. Each cell contains a reeking chamber pot and no other furnishings.

Imprisoned in the westernmost cell along the north wall is Hyustus Staget, a captain of the City Watch whom the characters have met (see "The Watch Arrives"). He was kidnapped while off duty and is without his armor and weapons. If Hyustus has died for whatever reason, replace him with a female human Watch officer named Cressa Galavarco (LG female Tethyrian {@creature veteran} with no armor or weapons). Whoever is here has a date with an intellect devourer.

entries.name: God Figurine
entries: The figurine on the pedestal is crudely fashioned out of clay. It has the head of a hammerhead shark, the upper torso of a bare-chested male, dragon wings sprouting from its shoulders, and octopus tentacles where its legs should be. The kuo-toa modeled it after an imaginary god they call Garshoogah.

entries.name: X28. Guild Recreation Hall
entries: Deafeningly loud music and chatter fill this magically lit room, which is decorated like a tavern:

items: Ten human {@creature bandit||bandits} (members of the {@creature Xanathar|WDH} Guild) sit around two trellis tables, drinking Wyrmwizz Ale, smoking pipes, clapping their hands, and stomping their feet while two {@creature goblin||goblins} wearing chamber pots on their heads dance and sing atop a third table.
If he's not with {@creature Xanathar|WDH} in the arena ({@area X6|27a}), {@creature Noska Ur'gray|wdh} (see {@adventure appendix B|WDH|12}) is here, drinking with the others.
A wooden rack along the east wall holds five large ale barrels with spigots punched into them. Protruding from the ceiling above the barrels is a ghostly eyestalk (scrying sensor).

entries.name: Xanathar Guild Members
entries: These villains are celebrating the capture of an off-duty City Watch captain (see {@area X27|2b2}). Characters who eavesdrop on the chatter hear one guild member say, "We caught ourselves a Watch captain! {@creature Ahmaergo|WDH} says the boss is happier than a pink flumph, whatever that is. Today, free ale! Tomorrow, {@item gold|PHB} and glory!" This proclamation is followed by loud cheers.

entries.name: Goblins
entries: The goblins, Lulz and Vellix, are servers who have allowed themselves to get swept up in the reverie. If a fight breaks out, they hide under a table and throw themselves at the mercy of the party if the characters emerge victorious.

entries.name: Scrying Sensor
entries: The ghostly eyestalk is a magical sensor that allows one of the apprentice wizards in {@area X16|292} to monitor this room. See {@area X2|273} for more information.

entries.name: X29. Trapdoor
entries: At the top of a staircase is a landing with a ladder leading up to a stone trapdoor that requires a successful DC 12 Strength (Athletics) check to be lifted. The trapdoor opens into {@area X18|29a} above.

entries.name: X30. Xanathar's Gourmet Kitchen
